- Welcome to another episode
of, "Data Strategy Unravel."
I'm your host, Khendr'a Reid,

Principal Data Strategy
Tech Specialist here at AWS.

And today we're gonna talk
about how to take a lot
of the information that we've been sharing

over the last few videos when
it comes to Generative AI,

how you can build that
Modern Data Foundation.

And once you've done that, how
do we actually provide that
to the business users?

And one of the ways to do
that is with QuickSight,
as well as with Generative BI.
And so we're gonna talk about that
and more in today's episode.
And to help us with this discussion,
I have Jesse Gebhardt here.
Jesse, welcome to the show.

How about you take some
time to introduce yourself.
- Thanks, Khendr'a.
Thanks for the opportunity here as well.

- Yeah.
- Hi, everybody.
My name's Jesse Gebhardt.

I lead our QuickSight Solution
Architecture team worldwide,

and I've been with
QuickSight about seven years,
so since just after we started,
so just after we launched QuickSight.
So yeah, it's been quite a journey.

- Good, good, so, you know,
I've been really wanting

to have you on here really
to talk about QuickSight
and how customers can use that,

but also some of that
Generative BI capabilities
that are there within the tool as well.

So let's first start off with
what is Amazon QuickSight?
- Of course, all right, so for folks
who aren't familiar with it,

Amazon QuickSight is our
Business Intelligence Service
that we offer through AWS.

So, you know, we position
it as a unified BI service.

So what mean by that is not
only can you do dashboards,

kinda the traditional stuff,
even paginated reporting,

you know, even more traditional,
a little more Legacy,

you know, scheduled
operational type reporting.
But a lot of our customers embed

data experiences into
their own applications.
We've got the Natural Language Query

and the Generative BI stuff,
we're gonna talk about today.

But typically, like a lot
of customers have different
tools for each of those use cases,

but we offer all those
through one service.

QuickSight Serverless, you
get great performance with it,
with very flexible pricing models as well.
- Yeah, okay, and so, you know,
we have heard a lot about Amazon Q
and how there's Amazon Q for Business
and different areas within AWS as a whole,
but what is Amazon Q for QuickSight?

And then can you talk a little
bit about those Generative BI

capabilities that comes
along with that as well?
- Yeah, absolutely, so Amazon Q,

just think of it as like
they're Gen AI Assistants

across many different
aspects of AWS services
and also focus on different personas.

So when we talk about
Amazon Q in QuickSight,

it's kind of how we've
implemented a Gen AI Assistant
that's focused on business intelligence.

So we sometimes refer
to this as Generative BI
instead of Generative AI.

Those two terms are kind of
interchangeable in our world,
whether we're talking,

whether we say Amazon Q in
QuickSight or Generative BI,

just so you know, we're
talking the exact same thing.

But in terms of the capabilities
it actually brings to you,
you know, I kind of bucket them into
the two different personas.
So you've got a set of folks
who are building dashboards, you know,
more like an analyst type of user.

And then you have a set of
users, usually a bigger community
of users who are consumers, right?
They typically interact with dashboards
or they receive reports.

They're just trying to get
answers out of their data.

So first, if we talk about
that analyst persona,
with the Generative BI capabilities,
they can build dashboards just using
Natural Language Prompts,

just describing the type of
visuals they wanna create.

They can be very vague language,
they could be very precise.

You can also create
calculations with prompts.

And then once you kinda
have these visuals created,
you get your computations in them,

you can refine the
visuals with additional,
you know, instructions.

You know, say you wanted to
add conditional formatting,

or you wanted to change a field
or change some granularity.

All that's available just
using Gen AI prompts.
So that's focused on like helping analysts
build stuff faster.

Then we've got this
other set of capabilities

that's really focused on
your General Data consumer.
So they get to a dashboard,
maybe it's something new to them.
The first thing they could do
is generate an Executive Summary, like,

"I don't even know what I
should be looking at here.

So, we'll tease out
what are the key things,
key highlights in the data."

And then after that you may
have some further questions.
So then we offer a Q&A experience,
where you could ask any question you want,

again, either as vague or
specific as you'd like,

and we'll give you a
whole bunch of visuals,
like even like a full dashboard back,
to answer your questions.

Then the last thing there
on the consumer side is,

okay, you found something
interesting in the dashboard,

you now need to go communicate
this to somebody else, right?

You're preparing for a
meeting with your boss,
with a customer, and usually you prepare

like a PowerPoint deck or a
document, something like that.
So we offer these Data Stories,
which again, you can just enter a prompt,
you could pick some data that is relevant
and we'll build you like a full blown,

well structured story with
visuals from your dashboards
with Insights from those,
in like a presentation-ready kinda format.
So, sorry, a lot of talking,
but just to summarize,

we got Gen AI stuff
- [Khendr'a] Yeah.
- for like the authors,
the analyst kind of users,
and then for your more consumer type user.
- No, that's great detail, right?

Because you know, over
the last few videos,

we talked about being able
to provide a self-service
to the lineup business, right?
We did a video previously on data mesh
and how that really works.
And so with this capabilities here,

this is essentially what
you're doing, right?
Providing a line of business to be able

to create their own reports,
provide those insights

up to upper management,
whatever it may be.
And so now they can really sort of do

that without be relying on
another team or IT, et cetera,
to be able to do that for them.
No that's really cool.

- Yeah.
- So, I know that
before, you know, Amazon Q in QuickSight,
there was QuickSight Q, right?

- Correct.
- And so can you kinda talk

a little bit about what
the differences there are
or if there is any difference there?

- Sure, so you're right,
we did launch QuickSight Q

back at like reinvent,
so end of the year 2020.
So that's been in the marketplace
for, you know, a few years at least.

So that original QuickSight
Q, I'll over summarize,

but it was basically
like the Q&A experience,

being able to ask a
question, get an answer back.
We'd always give you like a single visual.
So we spent a lot of time trying to get,
you know, the most accurate answer
to various precise questions,
and that wasn't work lost.

So, what we did, you know,
in those past few years

and as we launched Amazon Q
as a little bit more widely,

you know, we've kinda
ingrained more LLMs into it

and then we've really just
improved the Q&A experience

from that original Amazon,
sorry, QuickSight Q.
So think of Amazon Q as QuickSight
as just the next generation of what we had
with QuickSight Q a few years ago.

So you can still answer
questions out of the data,

but we'll give you more than
one visual as a response.
It can be really vague.
We'll give you Natural Language Summaries.
- [Khendr'a] Yeah.
- So just a supercharged version

of original QuickSight Q.
(Khendr'a laughs)

- Yeah, okay, yeah, no, that's
great clarification there.
'Cause I know I've gotten questions around
what the differences are, et cetera,

but I'm glad you laid
it out pretty clearly
there for our viewers here.
And so the other piece is, you know,

you talk a little bit
about what the capabilities

are with QuickSight,
especially with Amazon Q
embedded within that.

So can you talk through
some of the customers
that are using this technology
and how they're really using it
to accelerate their time to insights?
- Yeah, I'd love to.
There's two maybe I'll touch on today.
One's a pretty cool one with the NFL,
the National Football League in the US.
So they collect kind of a tracking data
from on every player's shoulder pads
and the ball and the officials,
they've got little chips,
and they're tracking like XY coordinates
of every movement of every single play.
So what they do with that data,

is they bring it into AWS,
they crunch it through

some ML models, but what
they produce with that
is like some advanced statistics.
So like, if you're ever watching a game

and you ever hear, "Next
Gen Stats powered by AWS,"

like the interface that
both the broadcasters get
for this data is through QuickSight.

They expose it to like the
teams for post game analysis,

but even their own
internal teams in the NFL,
like say they're preparing for, you know,
"The Week of Games,"
and there's always like storylines
that they're preparing for each week.

They use QuickSight and Q in
QuickSight to help find like,

what are those really interesting,
excuse me, statistics.
So like whenever you hear, you know,

"This player ran X amount of
miles per hour on this play,"

or, "Here's Patrick Mahomes's
is completion percentage

while being pressured in the
fourth quarter on the road."
Like they have a Q Interface to be able
to go ask those type of questions

and just get those stats,
you know, instantaneously.
- Okay.
- So that's a cool one from the NFL.
I got another one if you're interested.
- Yeah, yeah.
- Cool, so Traeger Grills,

so if you're a hobby,
barbecuer, smoker, you know,

into that kind of stuff,
cooking your own food.

So Traeger Grills,
they're a really popular
brand in this space.

So the way they use Q
and Q in QuickSight is,

so they collect IoT data
from all those devices.

So like if you've got a
grill in your backyard,
they're collecting IoT data from that.

And then they have their
customer service data.
So they use Amazon Connect

for all their customer
service interactions.

So they combine those
two sets of data together

to allow 'em to answer some
pretty interesting questions.
So like one example they shared was,

say like a post, like a
historical kind of analysis
of both those sets of data, like,

"How frequently are
temperature variation issues,"

like when people contact them
about those types of issues,
how often is that resolved if they do like
a thermocouple replacement?
Like that was an example question

that one of their customer
success folks would ask.
But they also shared like that they,
there was always this myth that users
that gave them high net promoter scores,

like high NPS scores, like,
you know, filling out surveys

and whatnot, that the people
that gave them high NPS scores

were people that like used
the grills all the time.

Fairly logical, I don't know.
(Jesse laughs)

- [Khendr'a] Yeah.
- I feel like I might come

to that same conclusion, but
by combining like the IoT data
with the customer service data,

they found that there actually
wasn't much of a difference
from like those high NPS scores.
They actually had customers
that use the grills less frequently,

but still love them just
as much as the folks
that use them every day.

- Oh wow, okay, and that's
cool, that's cool to know.
'Cause I'm actually a very big barbecuer,
so that's actually pretty good.
It makes me wanna go get a Traeger now.

So, as we wrap up here,
(Jesse laugh)
you know, you shared a lot of information

our viewers learn more

resources for you as you get started.

here in the description after,
so it'll be easy for you to get to.

- But we've got like a,
"Getting Started Course,"

just like a one hour, just
understand the capabilities
of Q and QuickSight.

And then, so it's, we've
got like that one hour
"Getting Started Course."

Then we have some, also
some Hands-on Workshops.

So if you wanna spend like,
you know, an hour to two hours,

like actually getting hands-on
experiencing it yourself,

we've got a great workshop

you know, complete on your own time,

And then lastly, like, we have this
Public Facing Demo Portal,

what this might look like on
different types of data sets,

we've got, you know, dozens
of different examples

types of industries,

different types of, you know,
verticals and horizontals,
all different use cases,

where we have these Q
capabilities turned on there.

So you can go, you know,
type some questions
and explore the data on lots

So we call that portal Demo Central.

for sharing that information.

we'll put those links
